title: Scientist
description: You are naturally curious and enjoy solving complex problems. You are methodical, analytical, and enjoy using data and research to drive your decisions.
detailedDescription: You’re an intensely curious person with a drive to learn how things work or make groundbreaking discoveries. You may enjoy reading a patient’s lab results to find things a physician can help them improve—or you may be driven to cure a disease or find a treatment that will change many lives. You probably have a background in science but may also be a skilled writer.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Scientist likes to figure out how things work and wants to make groundbreaking discoveries.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled at critical thinking, observation, and data analysis. They can also communicate complex ideas simply while speaking and writing.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Scientist’s path usually work with other scientists or medical professionals.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: A lab or university are the most common workplaces for The Scientist, but they may also work in a hospital or office.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Jobs in this field often require at least a bachelor’s degree in a physical science, and many prefer a Ph.D. or medical degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience working in a lab setting or doing research and writing proposals tend to be a good fit for The Scientist’s career path.

degreeTabs.title: Doctoral
degreeTabs.content:
PhD programs for medical scientists typically focus on research in a particular field, such as immunology, neurology, or cancer. Popular PhD options include:

  • PhD in Biology: This degree can prepare you for research in fields such as microbiology, environmental science, pharmaceutical development, genetics and more
  • PhD in Chemistry: This degree can prepare you for research in fields such as pharmacology, biomedicine, toxicology, and more.

Medical scientists also may pursue these medical degrees:

  • Medical Doctor (MD)
  • Doctor of Dental Surgery (DDS)
  • Doctor of Dental Medicine (DMD)
  • Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine (DO)
  • Doctor of Pharmacy (PharmD)
  • Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP)

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
A good master’s degree for those pursuing a medical science career is a Master of Science in Medical Science. It’s goal is to help medical students prepare to become competent physicians, but it can also prepare you for a more research-focused career.

Another option is the Master of Science in Clinical Research, which focuses more on quantitative and analytic skills in patient-oriented and translational research, as well as more traditional clinical investigation.

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you’re just getting started down the path of The Scientist, it’s a good idea to earn your Bachelor of Science in Biology or Chemistry. This will give you a strong foundation for future degrees.

Another options is a Bachelor of Science in Health Sciences, which can give you a strong skill base for clinical research. You’ll get an learn how to conduct research studies to ensure the safety and effectiveness of new drugs, devices, diagnostics and treatment regimens.
